issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

resolution.description: All attempts at reproducing this issue failed, or not enough information was available to reproduce the issue. Reading the code produces no clues as to why this behavior would occur. If more information appears later, please reopen the issue.
resolution.name: Cannot Reproduce

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

fields.description:
In VPC, ELB VMs have 2 ENIs attached to it. Strangely, when doing 'ifup eth1', dhcp offer to the secondary ENI is always slow -- time out after 45 seconds, and then IP is offered after 20 seconds. 

Then I tried to test with 3rd ENI. DHCP offer to the 3rd ENI is fast again. 

This is consistent behavior from service image (centos 7) with ec2-net-utils.

[2nd ENI]
Apr  5 21:54:53 localhost NetworkManager[415]: <info>  (eth1): link connected

Apr  5 21:55:16 localhost NetworkManager[415]: <info>  ifcfg-rh: update /etc/sysconfig/network-scripts/ifcfg-eth1 (9c92fad9-6ecb-3e6c-eb4d-8a47

fields.summary: DHCP offer to secondary ENI is very slow

comments.body:
[~spark], without ec2-net-utils and NetworkManager I do not see DHCP problems.

{code}
[root@euca-172-31-9-78 network-scripts]# time ifup eth1

Determining IP information for eth1... done.

real    0m2.648s
user    0m0.298s
sys     0m0.026s

And in /var/log/messages:
Apr 20 20:52:45 localhost dhclient[8900]: DHCPDISCOVER on eth1 to 255.255.255.255 port 67 interval 3 (xid=0x6d490c32)
Apr 20 20:52:45 localhost dhclient[8900]: DHCPREQUEST on eth1 to 255.255.255.255 port 67 (xid=0x6d490c32)
Apr 20 20:52:45 localhost dhclient[8900]: DHCPOFFER from 172.31.16.1
Apr 20 20:52:45 localhost dhclient[8900]: DHCPACK from 172.31.16.1 (xid=0x6d490c32)
Apr 20 20:52:47 localhost NET[8942]: /usr/sbin/dhclient-script : updated /etc/resolv.conf
Apr 20 20:52:47 localhost dhclient[8900]: bound to 172.31.16.83 -- renewal in 33614 seconds.
{code}

There is no difference in MidoNet setup whether an interface is primary or secondary - i.e., DHCP server is setup on subnets, and it responds to DHCP requests of interfaces connected to the subnet (MidoNet does not know what are primary, what are secondary interfaces). The fact that eth2, in your setup, did not have problems is an indication that there is something in the guest configuration.
[~tsugawa] What was your guest OS? What was your method to bring up eth1?

Tested in both CentOS6 and CentOS7.
As above, just ifup eth1

[~tsugawa] It is strange that I can't reproduce this myself. ec2-net-utils and NM are both installed and there was no delay. This is a different cloud and I don't have the old setup that I had the problem. I'll assign this myself for now and continue to check.
I couldn't reproduce in the latest source.
